customer_addr:
500 Sea World Drive
San Diego, CA 92109

citations.narrative:
On January 26, 2025, a pregnant, adult, female bottlenose dolphin (ID # NOA0010122) was being housed in the medical
pool in the Dolphin Stadium Complex in preparation for parturition (birth of her calf). The medical pool is connected by two
gates to the Dolphin Stadium Pool Complex consisting of several pools housing multiple adult marine mammals including
dolphins and pilot whales. On January 26, 2025, facility personnel observed a newborn bottlenose dolphin calf swimming
with two adult dolphins in a pool immediately adjacent to the medical pool. Facility veterinarians and staff immediately
confirmed the calf belonged to the adult female dolphin in the medical pool and reunited the mother and calf. Facility staff
indicated they suspected the dolphin calf slipped between a gap in the metal rails on a pool ledge next to the gate
separating the two pools. Although the calf remained in a facility pool, it was not contained in the intended medical pool
with its mother. The pool enclosure, as constructed, failed to contain the animals as intended allowing the newborn calf to
enter an adjacent pool creating a potential for distress, injury, or death to the animal. The facility has implemented
preventive measures to ensure this does not happen again.
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities for marine mammals must be structurally sound and must be maintained in good
repair to protect the animals from injury, to contain the animals within the facility, and to restrict the entrance of unwanted
animals.
Corrected prior to the inspection on February 13, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
ALEXANDRA ANDRICOS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.101(a)(1) 
   
Facilities, general. 
On January 26, 2025, a pregnant, adult, female bottlenose dolphin (ID # NOA0010122) was being housed in the medical 
pool in the Dolphin Stadium Complex in preparation for parturition (birth of her calf). The medical pool is connected by two 
gates to the Dolphin Stadium Pool Complex consisting of several pools housing multiple adult marine mammals including 
dolphins and pilot whales. On January 26, 2025, facility personnel observed a newborn bottlenose dolphin calf swimming 
with two adult dolphins in a pool immediately adjacent to the medical pool. Facility veterinarians and staff immediately 
confirmed the calf belonged to the adult female dolphin in the medical pool and reunited the mother and calf. Facility staff 
indicated they suspected the dolphin calf slipped between a gap in the metal rails on a pool ledge next to the gate 
separating the two pools. Although the calf remained in a facility pool, it was not contained in the intended medical pool 
with its mother. The pool enclosure, as constructed, failed to contain the animals as intended allowing the newborn calf to 
enter an adjacent pool creating a potential for distress, injury, or death to the animal. The facility has implemented 
preventive measures to ensure this does not happen again.  
 
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities for marine mammals must be structurally sound and must be maintained in good 
repair to protect the animals from injury, to contain the animals within the facility, and to restrict the entrance of unwanted 
animals. 
 
Corrected prior to the inspection on February 13, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ALEXANDRA ANDRICOS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
